page.title: 03EVIDENCE OF RURAL HISTORY
page.content: Two centuries ago the occupants of the cottages at Bottom o'th' Moor, used to be hand loom weavers.The looms were housed in the cellars or on the ground floor. Other locals wer employed in the bleaching industry, at either Harwood Vale or Firwood works. The "Green" was the centre of the cottages at Bottom o'th' Moor. It was used for Sunday School field days and other events. The Bolton and Bury boundary follows Blackshaw Brook across Breightmet golf course. At Arthur Lane farm ther is evidence of the old law concerning glass tax. This can be seen in the barn as the windows are bricked up. Adjoining the farm is a reservoir where skating parties were held by Thomas Hardcastle who was the owner of the Firwood works. Two other reservoirs near Red Lane have now dried up.
